Frequently Asked Questions

Most NZ lenders require a credit score of 500+ for personal loan approval. However, requirements vary by lender. Those with excellent credit (700+) typically qualify for the lowest interest rates, while borrowers with fair credit (500-650) may still qualify but at higher rates. Some online lenders like Harmoney and Nectar are more flexible with credit requirements.
Personal loan amounts in New Zealand typically range from $1,000 to $70,000, depending on the lender and your financial situation. Factors affecting your borrowing limit include income, existing debts, credit history, and employment status. The major banks typically offer up to $50,000, while some lenders like Westpac and Harmoney offer up to $70,000.
Personal loan interest rates in New Zealand currently range from approximately 8.99% to 29.99% p.a. The rate you receive depends on your credit profile, loan amount, and term length. Secured loans typically offer lower rates than unsecured options. The best rates (under 10%) are usually reserved for borrowers with excellent credit.
Online lenders can provide approval decisions within minutes to a few hours. Traditional banks may take 1-3 business days. Once approved, funds are typically disbursed within 1-2 business days, though some lenders offer same-day funding for existing customers. ANZ, for example, offers same-day approval for existing customers.
Most NZ lenders allow early repayment, but policies vary. Some charge early repayment fees (typically 1-2% of the remaining balance), while others like ANZ and ASB offer fee-free early repayment. Always check the terms before signing, and look for lenders that specifically advertise no early repayment fees.
Typically you'll need proof of identity (passport or driver's licence), proof of income (payslips or tax returns), bank statements from the last 3 months, and proof of address. Self-employed applicants may need additional documentation such as financial statements. Most online lenders can verify income digitally, speeding up the process.
